docs.lead_paragraph: My 12-year-old son gets migraines. He will call from the school nurse's office, head pounding, light stabbing at his eyes. I will drop what I am writing and bring him home, because sleep is his only real relief. I spend the rest of the day fidgeting and pacing, and the rest of the week distracted with worry. Evan's sickness wraps itself around my work once a month or less. Which means I have no clue what Michelle Rago goes through every single day. Most working parents use all their energy balancing the demands of work and home. But parents of chronically ill children -- her 7-year-old son Trent has diabetes -- bear the burden of what she describes as ''trying to keep our children alive and healthy, while attempting to balance the demands of work and home.''

headline.main: A Sick Child Tips the Balance for Parents

docs.abstract: Life's Work column on extereme difficulty of working and caring for child with chronic illness; attorney Michelle Rago explains decision to take leave to care for son, whose diabetes requires constant monitoring (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With two contracts that could affect 6,000 workers in the state set to expire April 3, negotiations between SBC Connecticut and the Communications Workers of America began last week. Both company and union officials said the cost of heath care benefits would be a major issue.

headline.main: Health Care Issue a Priority In SBC Contract Discussions

docs.abstract: Communications Workers of America Local 1298, whose contracts affecting 6,000 workers are due to expire on April 3, begins negotiations with SBC Connecticut; health care benefits is major issue (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One-half of the American psyche wants the best health care and the other half doesn't want to pay for it.

headline.main: The Promise and Cost Of Health Care

docs.abstract: National Committee for Quality Assurance president Margaret E O'Kane letter on Daniel Gross's Feb 8 column urges reining in health care costs by focusing on quality
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     One-half of the American psyche wants the best health care and the other half doesn't want to pay for it.

docs.lead_paragraph: SO what does it mean that gay rights activists, once the standard-bearers for sexual freedom, are now preoccupied with the sober institution of marriage -- and fighting off President Bush's plans for a constitutional amendment against same-sex marriage? The glories of marriage have not historically had top billing in the gay rights movement. Indeed, until the advent of AIDS, activists dwelt more on the joy of sexual liberation. But these days, the movement has a very different tone.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Marriage-Minded; The Gay Rights Movement, Settled Down

docs.abstract: Gay rights activists, once standard-bearers for sexual freedom, are now preoccupied with sober institution of marriage and fighting off Pres Bush's plan for constitutional amendment against same-sex marriage; turn in gay rights debate comes at time of widespread attention to benefits of marriage, for individual and society; photos (M)
